The outright, absolute and very public condemnations of the Senator seem to be an exercise in "virtue signalling" writ large. What she said may not be politically correct, it might be controversial and you may not agree.  But the criticisms of her speak volumes about the people making them - such vitriol, dismissiveness, condescension, ...rife with the insertion of straw man and ad hominem arguments. Add to that, the accusations that the Senator is wholly malicious in her intentions and completely incompetent.  - What is this need to ascribe malice, when there clearly is none? Why attack, when you are free to present your counter solutions? Why cherrypick an unbalanced picture of her words (as certain media outlets have done)? Why silence, when you can try to understand another's sincere and positive motives. Look for the grains of truth (and the larger truths as well). Disagree if you like. Passionately if you wish. But for many I think the phrase "thou doth protest too much" applies.

Let me get this straight. I need to have my knee replaced but my doctor tells me he can't get an operating room for a year. He's got the time to do it but the system either doesn't have enough facilities or won't pay him to use them more often. He works at a private clinic when he can't get time in the public hospital, however, and for a price I can have it next week. The public system 'covers' me for something he can't provide on a timely basis  because the system cannot hire him on a full time basis because they don't have enough facilities time but I can't buy his time and facility time that belongs to him and not the system. Does the government own the doctor, does it own his time all of the time? If the system can't use the amount of time he is available, why should it prevent him from selling it? Why are other skilled people allowed to do so? Why should a surgeon not work when the government can't afford all of his or her time?

Corinthians 2:11 - “No one can know a person's thoughts except that person's own spirit, and no one can know God's thoughts except God's own spirit.”  Just as our life essence, our spirit, our soul, dwells within our physical body, God's life essence, His spirit, His Self, dwells within Him.  Just as our spirit and our soul cannot be divided one from the other, neither can God's spirit, His Self, be divided.  God is Spirit, Spirit is God.  The word which we render as Spirit is Pneuma in the Greek, and Ruach in the Hebrew - wind; by resemblance, breath.  The Spirit of God is the breath, breathings, life force which is God.  Not of God, but is God.  The Spirit of God, is both the Father Himself, and Jesus Himself.  The Father is the Spirit; Jesus is the Spirit.  The Spirit is the Father, the Spirit is Jesus.  The Spirit is not an essence within which the Father and the Son have their existence, they are that essence, the Spirit is they.

Someday, perhaps partly because of the Indian Residential Schools Truth and Reconciliation Commission and its 94 Calls to Action, someone will ask: If we have learned to change our views of the Indian Residential Schools because of the violence inherent in that system, then why is it that we still look at violence, especially these battles, as the birth of a nation?

I love the stories of the 20th Century wars, I really do. They are critical in reaching an understanding of my parents and, therefore, of myself. But I also know we must let some things go if we are to have a visionary, justice seeking place in the future

 I am not saying we should forget, but there is truth that doesn't get visited enough, and, perhaps, still a little reconciliation as we live in the shadow of lives ruined by war.

The Indian Residential Schools system and World War 1, in particular, were part of an idea that Canada must be British. It is time to consider the possibility that that doesn't make sense.

Your analysis is too limited in scope. The US and Canadian Coast Guard both have  major concerns about the increase in tankers coming out of Canada, which you've not included in your review. Kinder Morgan anticipates doubling the capacity of its Trans-Mountain Pipeline. Even with the use of larger capacity tankers, this increases tanker traffic, from BC, substantially. While US efforts to safely transport oil out of our region have been very effective, the major concern is that Canada, while planning to have an additional six stations for oil spill response, is not ready for the proposed increase in tanker traffic from Canadian ports. Oil industry maps and modeling show that oil spills in Canadian waters will not respect national boundaries.

The other issues under study are the toxicity of diluted bitumen — a heavy oil that is more difficult to contain and clean up than crude or refined oil and the ability to clean up any oil product when ocean conditions are not favorable.

The Native Hawaiian Health Care Improvement Act of 1992 grants $14 million every year to a Native Hawaiian Health System that today mostly emulates the common community health clinic.  The organizing board of the System is OHA, State Dept of Health, U.H., Alu Like, and a dissolved NHO.  Congress left the Act for dead in 2002 refusing reauthorization.  But a powerful Sen. Inouye funded it every year since then through entitlement setasides.  Inouye creatively resurrected the Act in 2011 just before his death by coattailing the Act to Obamacare (Affordable Care Act).  The meandering System terminates in 2019 unless the Republican Congress separately reauthorizes it.  However, its funding through the US DHHS could end abruptly if Congress refuses apportionment follow through.  Additionally, if Obamacare is repealed and replaced, its repeal immediately repeals its coattail, i.e. the Native Hawaiian Health Care Improvement Act.

Regarding: "Nothing in the Church's teaching would have precluded your grandmother separating from your grandfather. Blaming her ignorance of the Church's teaching on "Burke and co" or anyone else doesn't advance your argument."
- By way of an historical moment: in the US separation and divorce was very discouraged. Indeed, a divorced women was held with little regard even by clergy. Indeed, divorce for a woman was a a sure indicator of a future of destitution.  In US catholic literature on marriage in those days, especially written for pastors, there was no, 'if he hits you, then leave'. More like: 'if he hits you, then try harder to love him and be a good wife.'
- So, while grandmother might have known that the US bishop rescinded in 1884 their 1840 degree that divorce incurs automatic excommunication, she would be still certain that her vows meant something, and that her church, in those days, would have little sympathy for her as divorced or separated.

You can't base upkeep costs on a fictional percentage of the mortgage. Yes you will need to replace a roof and furnance during any 25 year period, that amounts to $15k in 25 years. You should replace your windows and outside doors once every 25 years, thats another $25k. Thats $40k, where is the other $66,250 in upkeep costs coming from? Even if you rent, the cost of property taxes are factored into your rent payments so you can't include that figure. Thats another $106,250 off the top.

Take that $797,122 and deduct $106,255 for property taxes, $66,250 of non-existant upkeep costs and you get $624,617 you can sell that home for $1 million leaving a profit of $375,383 after 25 years.

The bottom line is this: they are on private property and they have to be removed.  It's really that simple.  I can't just set up shop in your backyard and "protest" the shed that you want to build that you've already been permitted for.  I can't just stand in your backyard and physically block you from constructing the shed.  I can't wave signs in your face saying "stop the shed building."  You would be right to call the police, and if I refused to leave, they would be right to physically remove me, with force if necessary.  

That's not a "right."  There is no such thing as the "right to protest" on someone else's property.  Never has been and never will be.  You don't have that "right."  Nobody does.  You can protest all you want on your own property, or on public property, but not on someone else's property.  These protesters will be removed for the same reason I would be removed from your backyard if I were "protesting" there.  No different at all.

There is a danger in the idea that we are our body, that our body (or actually our self-reports or feelings of our body) always points to the good and the true.

Anorexics rely on their self-reports.  And they're horrifically wrong. 

Some people have relied on "self-reports" of their body & gotten a sex change operation, but have decided in later years to reverse it!

So discerning the truth and the good takes work; it doesn't simply come "naturally".  We can get it wrong.

Our body is given to us to master, to develop, to use, to put to God's work. 

We often have to temper our feelings, our self-reports of our body.."no, you don't need more booze, chow, sex in the middle of the subway."

We have to temper some (what our emotions might insist as) "cravings" of our body.

We have to sometimes push our body around in order to serve the good. Tell it who is the boss. 

The body is not the boss.

The "why of my body" often has less to do with "my body" than it does my soul.

Many of us who live on the lower Cook Inlet remember this somewhat differently. We observed humpback whales staying in our waters later than anyone could ever remember seeing; through September, October, into November, and many until the first of the year. There were extraordinary numbers of murres as well, staying well past the traditional time when this species would migrate from the region.

These creatures didn't linger because there was a lack of food, on the contrary, there was a tremendous amount of food, and temperatures were unseasonably warm. Those of us who took to the water (from Koyuktolic Bay to the head of Kachemak) saw tremendous balls of bait  fish.

These bait fish often leave our waters as quickly as they arrive. In less than a week's time, early November, a great preponderance of these balls of bait left the area. The murres had stayed too long. A heavy 80 knot wind hit the area and caught the birds unawares. Blowing them inland all the way to Lake Illiamna.

Passing on the right  is not "illegal" in Oregon on a four-lane highway.  Or even on some other highways.  

ORS 811.415 (2)

For purposes of this section, a person may drive a vehicle to overtake and pass upon the right of another vehicle under any of the following circumstances:

(b) Overtaking and passing upon the right is permitted if the overtaken vehicle is proceeding along a roadway in the left lane of two or more clearly marked lanes allocated exclusively to vehicular traffic moving in the same direction as the overtaking driver.

It is also legal on some other highways if they are wide enough, for example when someone is making a left turn.  

In the olden days, that law only permitted this  inside City Limits;  that  is no longer the case.

The funding for education has increased substantially over the past 14 years or so. I am very sympathetic to this woman's basic gripe -- I lived for many years in Thailand, and constantly engaging with people's stereotyped idea of what you should look like, how you should behave, what you should think, is annoying.  To have to do that in your native land and culture would be massively aggravating.

However, I think a lot of the problem here is that 'race' is a weird mixture of biology, cultural myth, and habit.  Biologically, it doesn't exist; socially, it does, and socially, being 'black' is one of the more charged identities.  My children, for example, are part American Mennonite and part Asian -- they'll get to work out what this means for them on their own, and the people they interact with will have minimal expectations.

As for the writer, what does she expect?  'Black' after all, is a visual identification; some people will depend on that, including some black people.  Many ethnic identities have certain signifiers, that some people meet easily, others not.

The plethora of UK consumer price indices is confusing : the UK CPI rose from 2.7% in April to 2.9% in May, as opposed to the CPIH, up from 2.4% to 2.5%, the RPI, up from 3.5% to 3.7%, and the RPIJ, up from 2.8% to 2.9%. The latter is just the RPI adjusted to remove the so-called formula effect which gave the RPI an upward bias. It hasn’t been calculated since the January 2017 update, but since the impact of the formula effect on the RPI annual inflation rate is still published, for all intents and purposes the ONS still publishes the RPIJ annual inflation rate. The RPI/RPIJ should have been reformed to include stamp duty (i.e. land transfer taxes), heavily influenced by rising house prices, but this still hasn’t happened. If one added a stamp duty component to the RPIJ, it might already be showing a 3.0% inflation rate in May. The true rate of inflation as far as UK households are concerned is probably already at or above three percent.

My dad was a 18 year old American Indian from a reservation in New Mexico when he joined the Army after graduation. After basic training, he boarded a ship (he had never been on a ship or the ocean before) and sailed off to a unknown destination. He remembers getting very sea sick, the change in the temperature and nothing but miles of ocean. Eventually they arrived in Alaska and headed out to the Aleutians. 
I grew up hearing all about the Aleutians, especially Kiska, and Attu. 
It's ironic, at 21, I ended up living here for the last 44 years. 
He has many stories about Alaska and the war. After the war he returned to the reservation but he never forgot Kiska or Attu.
 "The wind howled all night and it drove men crazy," he would say.  We tried to imagine "a place without trees as far as you could see" but couldn't.
He spoke of the weather and Japanese attacking a Army hospital. No ill feelings towards the Japanese. He had gone to school with some and said it was war. He is 93 now.

"Michelson-Morely experiment that FAILED to prove the earth moves. Or how aboutThe Michelson-Gale experiment? What about Airey's failure? The Sagnac experiment?"

Because, as Einstein demonstrated, physics in a reference frame are unchanged by its velocity relative to other frames. Relative to those experiments, the earth was not moving.

Do your own experiment: get in the passenger seat of your car with a baseball. Toss it in the air in front of you. Now, have someone drive at a stable speed. Toss it in the air again. Do you notice how its trajectory is essentially the same?  That's how reference frames work.

All of those experiments started with the flawed assertion: that there's 𝘴𝘰𝘮𝘦𝘵𝘩𝘪𝘯𝘨 that violated that rule - luminerous aether - and that they could detect it.  That's why all of those experiments failed.

The Pacific Northwest is fairly well protected with Ground Based Interceptors in Alaska and California positioned to kill Nork ICBMs transiting the Great Circle route from Korea to the US.  But the rest of the US isn't as well protected.  Should the Norks fire an ICBM into an orbital route to the South, we are very vulnerable since there is no Upgraded Early Warning Radar (UEWR) in the Southern US, nor is there an X-Band Radar for Terminal Guidance, or a Ground Based Interceptor (GBI) silo farm.  The Missile Defense Agency is considering sites in the Northeast to intercept an Iranian ICBM,  but I've seen nothing about a Southern defense.  So,  we are in a race with the Norks and Iranians to see whether they can build an ICBM that achieve orbit to the South before we build a defense.  The bad news for us is that we aren't doing anything, while our enemies are.

The only well established case where small pox infested blankets were distributed to native Americans  was during Pontiac's rebellion when they were besieging the British and American colonists at Fort Pitt (Pittsburgh). What effect that might have  had  on the more general small pox epidemic at the time affecting native Americans and settlers  at the time is moot. (You might want to read about Pontiac's rebellion. The brutality was rather two-way.)  There aren't, so far as I know, instances of the Hudson's Bay Company or the Northwest Company or their agents in Canada distributing small pox infested blankets. The reason is that fur trading companies depended on aboriginal suppliers for their furs and much else for survival. Killing off your suppliers would be a self-destructive way of doing business.  That isn't to say that small pox wasn't a scourge among Canadian aboriginals but its spread was through human contact.

I have no reason whatsoever to doubt Mr. Morneau's integrity. I feel that he is in public service for the right reasons. As the Minister of Finance, his department ultimately regulates and influences much of the pension industry. His family's firm is a major player in that industry. "The Parks and Recreation Commission and municipal Department of Parks and Recreation are big fans of singletrack trails because the users are well organized and pay for the trails themselves."

And they organize and set up trail-work days, clear dead-fall across the trails, clear brush close to the trail to ensure the trails stay safe, set up trail signs, etc.  It's not just these things, but also the design of the trails, if advanced features are included, ride-arounds are offered, sight-lines are preserved, grade-reversals are used, etc.  So from a land management point of view, the group mitigates many of the possible concerns that come from allowing the building of trails and avoids many of the design-disasters of previous older trails.

My (vast) experience in villages is:

- Where alcohol is legal; people get drunk more often, but not massively drunk as often. And when problems arise (and they always do) the attitude is, "We wouldn't have these problems if we were dry. Blame the law."

- Where alcohol is illegal; people don't get drunk as often, but when they do they go all out. (Nobody wants to get caught with a "jug" so they destroy the evidence.) And when problems arise (and they always do) the attitude is, "We have these problems because the Troopers/teachers/health aides aren't doing their job. Blame 'those other' people."

In my humble opinion, a dry community creates more problems than it solves. And laws against importation are so weak that they have little effect on bootleggers.

In my opinion opening the bank account should occur around the same time the allowance starts.  As the column notes the accounts don't cost anything, and the lessons from just visiting the bank at a young age and making deposits will be an invaluable lesson.  Sure the interest rates these days don't amount to anything but neither do piggy banks.  It is more the mental exercise that saving money for the future is a good thing to do.

I don't buy into the allowance concept as I think it generally instills more bad habits than good.  Sure it teaches about budgeting but usually only from the perspective figuring out how to get your wants.  It doesn't teach anything about needs and savings all depend on the child or the influence of the parent. 

I think you can teach as much about budgeting and financial know-how by introducing them over time to your daily financial responsibilities.  Starting out with basic concepts and graduating to more complex items in line with their abilities.

The latest polls have been tending to show the Conservatives and Liberals in a near dead-heat in Ontario, which is really going to be the deciding factor.  Jagmeet Singh adds a whole new variable as might have the ability to change up the vote (one way or another) in the suburbs of Ontario where the elections tend to be decided.

For the time being the election map doesn't look too different than any of the past 6 elections (with the exception of the unexpectedly strong performance of the NDP in 2011).  The Liberals are doing well in the East, Quebec and in core-urban Ontario. The Conservatives are doing well in MB, SK, AB and most of BC other than Vancouver, as well as rural Ontario.  That gives either party 100+ seats, with about 50+ suburban Ontario seats being the deciding factor.  In 2000 and 2015 the Liberals won those seats.  In 2004, 2006, 2008 and 2011 they steadily shifted from Liberal to Conservative.

3. Like many private employers, the State would (alternately) be contributing towards 401k's (in many cases, as mandated by law).

Bottom Line: this is a pension system. There's no "wow" in this formula. Government isn't subsidizing private employers who dump their retirement burdens off on taxpayers a few decades in the future - here, the burden is demanded up-front, preemptively so future taxpayers aren't burdened. Unfortunately, Colorado wants to do the worst of both: commit to a conservative approach by funding this liability in advance but also not funding it so taxpayers in 2030, or 2040, or 2050 have to make up the difference. If some alternative appears cheaper to you that's because costs are being shifted or ignored.

People who allow their pet to roam un-tethered have rationalized their behavior and found a community of like-minded people, many of whom speak in a manner that indicates they truly believe they are morally superior to those who would "limit" their pets. And really, their behavior is rational. Don't we all seek to maximize benefit and minimize cost in nearly everything we do? Pet owners who refuse responsibility for restraining their pet seek to maximize the benefits of pet ownership (companionship, defense, conversational ice-breaker, etc.) while minimizing the cost (financial and convenience-wise). Meanwhile, the rest of us, including responsible pet owners, the pets themselves, and wildlife bear much of those costs. This practice is called externalizing costs, and it is how many industries, industries for which many of us have low regard, have made a great deal of money.

People often look at home/road splits and assume that the road splits are a players's "true" stats, and anything they do above that at home is added by their home park. For most teams that's true, but there is mounting evidence that for Rockies players, playing half their games at high altitude actually makes their road stats worse than if they played for any other team. So while Helton's career home stats of .345/.442/.607 are certainly not a true indicator of his ability, his .287/.386/.470 road split is just as suspect. So for Rockies players, their true stats are somewhere in the middle, and Helton's overall numbers are probably pretty close to what he would have done as a member of any other team.

The Rockies really should start some sort of campaign educating baseball writers and fans of how Coors Field really works and build some support for guys like Helton and Walker. If guys like those two don't make it into the hall, I have to wonder if ANY Rockies player has a chance?

Funneling public money away from an already strapped public school system is simply a way to finally undermine and destroy it.  Where will the poor kids be then?  

Charter schools can be incorporated into existing school districts as experiments into alternate methods of education, and as long as they meet the test of being able to field the special needs students, the disadvantaged, and the same broad cross-section of the population as are represented in public schools, I have no problem with them at all.

Vouchers on the other hand are a naked attempt to strip money from that system, and funnel it to schools with little or no public accountability standards.

Interesting article. I had always assumed that "white death" referred to the macroscopic appearance of the tuberculous nodules. Tuberculosis causes a form of inflammation called "caseous granulomatous inflammation". The term "caseous" means "cheese-like" and granulomas are nodules created essentially by macrophages clustering together to try to kill microbes. In tuberculosis, these nodules are filled with necrotic (i.e., "dead") tissue that looks macroscopically like white cottage cheese (pathologists have traditionally loved to describe disease processes in culinary terms). The reference to patients' general pallor also makes sense, but anemic pallor is common to many chronic illnesses whereas caseous granulomas are much more (although not completely) specific to tuberculosis.

During the Wojtyla/Ratzinger years, we witnessed a gradual, but not subtle, emergence of a new ultramontanism that is aptly called "creeping" (creepy!) infallibility. Infallibility was often invoked (not always explicitly) in a way that tends to collapse the traditional articulation of distinct levels of authority and response. For instance, Pope John Paul never explicitly invoked infallibility to shore up his teaching about the ordination of women; neither did Pope Benedict. But Cardinal Ratzinger, as prefect of the CDF, did; in doing so, Ratzinger did not in any respect add to or detract from what JP had already written. 
I bring this up to argue that this fuzzy way of thinking about church teaching, about authority, response and reception of church teaching, about conscience formation has a provenance in recent papacies. Trad and RR both evince ignorance of the Catholic tradition; but they may have heard these distortions in Catholic classrooms or pulpits in the past 25 years.

Henry VIII actually had solid grounds for an annulment, Catherine of Aragon had originally been married to Henry's brother, Arthur, who died. One needs a dispensation to marry your brother's widow, and Henry's father had pressured the Archbishop of Canterbury into giving it. Thus, Henry had a justified claim that the dispensation was improperly given.

However, Catherine opposed the annulment, probably because she didn't want her daughter Mary to lose her place as Henry's heir. So she claimed that she  had never consummated her marriage to Arthur. She also got her nephew, Charles II, to oppose the annulment. Charles, who disliked Henry both personally and politically, was happy to oblige his aunt.

Among other things, Charles was King of Naples. Naples and the Papal States had recently had a war. The pope lost, and didn't want a rerun. So he pretended to take Catherine's claim seriously.

Henry forced his hand when he broke with Rome. That's why the annulment was denied.

The risk of an earthquake is stupidly low compared to the risk of you failing to get out of bed tomorrow morning, but so what? It's meaningless to compare the risk of Black Swan events. It's intelligent to mitigate risks when possible. We can't stop an earthquake (natural) or an oil spill (human errors), both happen regularly, but we can make the effort to better deal with them when they happen. The long-term failure to make the effort to do a better job at cleaning up oil spills is what has to change, and can change, but only if the public demands it. Government and industry have failed on this file for the last 50 years and there is no sign that things are about to change for the better. For example, there have been no changes since BP's DWH cleanup fiasco in 2010 when they only recovered 3% (three) of the oil and toxified the environment, to this day, with chemical dispersant (the oil did not "go away"as it was supposed to).

This is a "semi-arid desert," and getting warmer fast, with less rainfall.

And roofs were not meant to be lawns.  Flat roofs leak under the best of conditions.  Imagine what will happen with all that water (drinking water) poured on them every day.  In order to have a "garden" of any type up there, a watering system will need to be installed, along with a complementary drainage system.  This is all going to be very expensive and wasteful.   All that water will percolate down through the few inches of soil into the drainage system, and thence, into the storm sewer.  Storm sewer costs will rise correspondingly.  I am actually surprised the city didn't oppose this ill-conceived notion vehemently.

Every investment carries risk and the Quebec government fully knew the risks. We took inflatable kayaks -- far more stable in whitewater than the inflatable canoes in the picture.  Grabners would also have been better.  We all wore drysuits, not splash gear, and all had swiftwater rescue training + lots of past experience.  Our best paddler went first while the rest of us waited, proceeding one at time down the trickiest part of the rapids.  He was on a gavel bar at the bottom of the run, with a throw bag, and as the rest of us completed our runs, we joined him with our throw bags.  None of us swam.  All  carried their own gear + food for 2+ weeks. I weigh only 108 lbs but refuse to be banned from running AK rivers by armchair 1/4backs, based on my age, size or gender.

@Philly_Canuck -- quote " I suspect that such limits may exist (thought experiment: What happens if you triple it overnight?)"

This is a great question.  If we take the US examples cited, in many cases there was minimal to no negative impact on working hours, though there was some correlation between the increase in minimum wage and a decrease in job formation.

At some point, if the minimum wage is high enough, it's a virtual certainty that there is a significant impact (i.e. if minimum wage became $50/hour).

So somewhere in between, presumably is a 'sweet spot' that maximizes the overall benefit while minimizing the downsides.  This could be a range of ratios relative to median incomes for example.  (a good start for a Masters' thesis if any aspiring economists are so inclined).

I'd hypothesize that the US results were more a function of the real minimum wage still being less than historical norms, even with the increases -- ergo limited job market impact.  To be determined...

As someone who has done Jurisdictional Determinations of waters of the US for over 500,000 acres of watershed, ephemeral waters are considered waters of the U.S. by the Army Corps unless it can be proven they do not possess a significant nexus with a downstream traditional navigable water. 

The 2015 Clean Water Rule would make "All waters located within the 100-year floodplain " waters of the U.S.  This is a Federal overreach in my opinion as most of the cites in Colorado (Denver, Boulder, Fort Collins) are built within the 100 year floodplain. That means if you live in these area and simply want to put a garden in your backyard you would have to apply for a 404 permit. Turn around time for 404 permits very from 3 weeks for small nationwide permits (< 1/10th and acre) to 18 months for larger projects. The cheapest ones will cost you about 10K$ and larger work up into the millions.

When I learned about rainfall calculations for growing crops it was based on land area and water input from rain, and frequency of rain (4 inches of rain in one day is different from 4 inches in 2 weeks).  If you want to do the calculations of how much water (and dilution rates), how long the water takes to percolate, etc., 1 inch of rain is ~27,000 gallons per acre, and will take thousands of years to get into the aquifer, vs the ~2 million acres of Mauna Kea at lower elevation that get way more rain and seeps into the aquifer more quickly. (ex. 3,780,000,000 gallons in 14,000 acres at the summit for 10 inches of rain a year, vs Laupahoehoe forest about the same size as the summit that gets 135 inches of rain per year (13.5 x as much rain in Laupahoehoe vs. summit), multiply this by another 1,986,000 to get a recharge rate comparison of wet areas on MK vs. the summit water input. About 27 million times more water could dilute the summit per year.

Many of the initiatives to change demand behaviour are credible, but have we sufficiently employed the most effective lever of all, namely price? The price that we pay for our potable water does not nearly reflect the real cost of delivering this resource to our taps. In other words, water is heavily subsidised, even for high water users (relatively wealthy residential and commercial customers). This crisis demands that we immediately enforce much higher water tariffs for high water users (I include myself here) in the context of the Western Cape as an arid area with chronic water shortages. The price increase needs to be a multiple of the current level in order to change behaviour meaningfully. IMHO this would be the most successful of all demand management strategies. Miraculously individuals and companies will change the way they use water, through simple economics, in much the same way as we have seen Eskom price hikes change electricity consumption.

One answer to JuJu Bean: if compassion isn't your thing, try self-interest. Providing for the homeless improves quality of life for everybody.  Ask people in downtown Seattle or San Francisco.  They think giving homeless people better options is worth real money, since otherwise they simply congregate and camp in public areas.  Policing them isn't effective (ties up too much manpower).  Pushing them out just moves the problem elsewhere.  And, though it may disappoint you, a Darwinian solution isn't available; we can't let people simply die on our streets.

The first reason housing is so effective is that it disperses a population that otherwise has little choice but to hang out together wherever they are tolerated. The second is that housing gives otherwise hopeless people a motive to start taking better care of themselves.  A third is that housing keep children off the streets and out of cars; even a Darwinian should be able to see the point of saving children.

I'm  an immigrant who took a citizenship oath many years ago, and I approve of this amendment. To the commenters who think they've found a logical error because individual citizens don't make treaties, look closely at the wording. Citizens are being asked to affirm that they will "faithfully observe the laws of Canada including treaties with Indigenous Peoples". In other words, "treaties with Indigenous Peoples" are a subset of the "laws of Canada". Individuals are not being asked to make treaties or to interpret them. Emphasizing this particular subset of Canadian laws makes historic sense, and is consistent with the idea of reconciliation, bringing to the forefront the nation-to-nation legal arrangements between indigenous and non-indigenous bodies which still apply in Canada today.

User fees in health care are necessary.  As a home owner, I hate to say this, but it is apparent that primary residences - should be - subject to capital gains - at the time - of sale.

The proceeds should NOT be general tax revenue, but go into the individual's special pension account. This should not be subject to any sort of "fairness" adjustment. All of the amount should be designated to the individual.

The pension account should boost the monthly payout to the individual with a part of the amount going into a special HSA (health savings account), which is restricted in payout. If there is a balance in this account, user fees can be designated by the individual resulting in expedited service - a second line for "user fee" payors.

This will relieve the pressure on the young people, workers, manufacturers, energy consumers, and the general economy, from rising health care costs, and also inject capital into the health system to increase service levels.

Those arguing for and against universal basic income tend to base their respective positions on sweeping assumptions about human nature. Those against it, for example, often argue that the scheme will sap people of their will to work and desire to better themselves, which rests on the supposition that money alone drives an individual to be productive. Those for it tend to exaggerate the extent to which providing basic material comforts alone result in happy citizens and a healthy society, an assumption that is belied by the poor socio-economic outcomes among current income assistance recipients in Canada.

Instead of debating human nature, a generally fruitless endeavour, we should simply test the idea in the real world to see if it works.  The Ontario government is right to pilot UBI, but the whole enterprise is dependent on the results being measured with brutal honesty and objectivity. If it doesn't work, we have to acknowledge it.

It is up to the federal government and provinces to set clear guidelines and priorities. Otherwise we get more of the current system and double dipping.

To begin: Yes, ADUs are a worthy concept, but the key is "accessory." "Springfield also is looking at ... including lifting a requirement that the property owner has to live on site and one that requires on-site parking be paved."

One of the reasons the condo market is rising is Vancouver's restrictions on the replacement of pre-1940's homes with new construction. Immigrant buyers are moving to that market and purchasing multiple units. Unfortunately, most generational buyers cannot compete with these immigrants when it comes to available capital. The federal government controls both the influx of  immigrants and their capital. As long as both continue to flow into Canada at the current rate, the displacement of generational Canadians will continue. The efforts of the provincial and civic governments to  deliver on their impossible promises of 'affordable housing' in the face of this inflow only further distort the markets and punish those generationals fortunate enough to hold property. There is no realistic way of dealing with the problem: Ottawa will not restrict immigration or capital and Vancouver cannot provide housing fast enough to make it 'affordable' for generationals. The displacement will continue.

"Rape is an outrage that cannot be tolerated in a civilized society." ~ Camille Paglia

Does that statement, by implication, mean that other forms of assault are not an outrage?

In my view, rape and other forms of sexual assault mustn't be viewed in a fundamentally different manner than other assaults. ALL assaults are a violation of an individual's physical and emotional well-being. For example, an unwanted slap on a woman's behind is a sexual assault. Is that a worse offence than slapping a man on the face? Which hurts more? Which is more demeaning?

Women are often victims of sexual assault. Feminists have drawn attention to that problem by claiming that it's a particularly pernicious form of assault. In doing so they've taken attention away from physical assault, which men experience at far higher rates than women.

The problem won't be fixed one gender at a time. No form of assault against anyone is acceptable, and all forms of assault must be condemned equally.

Actually that's not my premise. The police are within their jurisdiction to approach "sketchy" individuals in a high crime area (or any area for that matter) and ask questions. The individuals have a right to provide a limited answer, or not to answer at all. They have the right not to show their I.D. Any further attempt to detain is a violation of Section 9 of the Canadian Charter of Rights & Freedoms. Police already have jurisdiction to pull over any moving vehicle for whatever reason they want. Technically it should only be when "a constellation of objectively discernible facts...give the detaining officer reasonable cause to suspect that the detainee is criminally implicated in the activity under investigation," (sect. 9), not just "I'm looking for a black perp and hey, you're black." Keep in mind there is zero evidence that carding prevents or reduces crime, or leads to solving more crimes. Toronto Police could provide no evidence when asked by the Province.

The editors are spot-on in supporting this sensible win-win approach to offsetting  greenhouse gas emissions. Unfortunately they fail to mention the primary problem this approach solves: Aviation generated greenhouse gas emissions, Hawaii's #1 climate pollution challenge.   

2013 data indicated  that CO2 from tourist aviation alone was nearly twice that of all other sources in Hawaii combined.

Furthermore, unlike ground transportation and power generation, there are no viable clean energy alternatives to burning kerosene jet fuel.  The only practical solution is the use of carbon offsets. There is also significant opportunity in this approach. 

The nearly 10 million tourists coming to Hawaii each year are a potential source of revenue to support these carbon offset projects.

Capitalizing on this will take a cultural shift in the Hawaii tourism community, particularly with our Airlines. Marketing/educating visitors and facilitating their voluntary purchase of credits will be needed.

I don't drive this stretch, but I do have a theory on driver behavior in Anchorage. As traffic enforcement has gone down, drivers recognize the chances of being caught violating traffic ordinances are reduced. They then bend/break the law more often, and as long as they're not caught, their propensity to drive however they'd like increases. This becomes more and more prevalent with more and more drivers until  the dominant paradigm becomes drive however you'd like, no one's going to stop you (most likely). Increased and sustained traffic enforcement is the best way to reverse this trend.

The article is somewhat misleading when it states: "If you received eligible pension income in 2016 (sorry, but Canada Pension Plan benefits don’t qualify) you may be able to report up to one half of that income on your spouse’s tax return."  In fact, CPP benefits can be "split" with a spouse, up to 50%, through a process called "assignment"( this does have to be done in advance and can't be done retroactively for 2016).  The individual receiving CPP must contact Service Canada and request it. The "splitting" will then be reflected in the monthly CPP payments.  Here are two links with further info:

1) http://www.taxplanningguide.ca/tax-planning-guide/section-2-individuals/splitting-cpp-benefits-spouse-common-law-partner/

2) http://www.servicecanada.gc.ca/fi-if/index.jsp?app=prfl&frm=isp1002&lang=eng

Eugene has successful models for transitional  and emergency homeless shelter, Opportunity Village and the "rest stop" camps, all run by local nonprofits using city or county land. These could be expanded, but the problem is neighborhood opposition. So the neighborhoods end up with messy illegal unorganized homeless camps instead of organized legal ones, and then constantly complain about it. The homeless are not going to suddenly disappear so it would make more sense to provide legal shelter. 

It is also cheaper, when you consider all the money that goes into policing, courts, jails, ER visits, park cleaning, etc. This has been proven in other cities that have adopted a "housing first" policy of providing subsidized housing with no preconditions, such as treatment for addictions or mental illness, but provided those as supports for people who want them. Most succeed in staying housed.

So, the department of education will teach the basic skills, but it is the responsibility of parents and guardians to ensure the child is educated.

Your analogy is flawed - apples and orangutans.  This is an individual who has been found to have had his charter rights breached by government action and inaction.  

It is not a case alleging a law is unconstitutional and dealt with under the remedy at s. 52(1).

If an individual's Charter rights have been breached there are broad remedies available - see s.24(1).  The section says if an individual's rights are breached he/she can "obtain such remedy as the court considers appropriate and just in the circumstances" and in this case the remedy is an award of damages.

S. 24(1) must be distinguished from s 52(1) of the Constitution Act, 1982. Whereas section 52 allows the courts to invalidate laws or parts of laws for breaches of the constitution (including the Charter), section 24 has broader capabilities.  That was the situation in the prostitution case where s. 52(1) was applied.
